awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  An Integrative Field and Biophysical Model of Thermal Stress, Physiological Performance, and Reproductive Fitness
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals experience thermal stress at the extremes of their geographic range. This stress may be compounded by climate change, especially when the geographic range stretches over a large range of latitude. Many species use behavioral thermoregulation to ameliorate heat stress.  However, these compensatory behaviors have a cost, as they require the animal to abandon critical behaviors that may only be performed in the hot and stressful habitat. This study investigates these survival/reproductive tradeoffs in fiddler crabs, small semi-terrestrial crabs that occupy shorelines in the tropics and temperate zones. Male fiddler crabs use visual displays to attract mates in the hot, dry intertidal zone, but must periodically retreat to a cool, moist burrow to rehydrate and recover. Each retreat to a burrow requires a cessation of mating behavior. Periodically the males rereat from the hot reproductive areas to rehydrate and feed. This study will determine the tradeoff between thermoregulation and mating performance across a species' geographic range, using both experimental and modeling approaches, under both current and predicted future conditions. Finally, the project will utilize the results of the research on fiddler crabs to increase public interest in science using public outreach activities and the training students at different levels including high school students. 

Behavioral compensation for thermal stress can lead to a profound but under-investigated tradeoff, as thermoregulatory behaviors are costly. Energetic and thermoregulation costs will generate major reproductive opportunity costs, which can reduce mating success. This project focuses on the fitness consequences of missed mating opportunities associated with thermoregulatory behaviors. These missed opportunities are crucial to understand in the study of mating success in the context of physiological stress and the differences in costs at different latitudes. Understanding the associated reductions in fitness are crucial to fully understand and predict the consequences of climate change on fitness, since heating in lower latitudes may truncate the benefit of mating owing to the increased cost of thermal stress. This proposal takes an integrative approach, combining laboratory measurements, manipulative field experiments, and biophysical modeling to examine the fitness consequences of behavioral thermoregulation. This work, and the resulting model, will be broadly applicable to the study of climate change impacts on ectotherms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have accomplished all of our goals for our portion of the collaborative NSF grant, "An Integrative Field and Biophysical Model of Thermal Stress, Physiological Performance, and Reproductive Fitness" . We have one published paper(Mathewson et al. 2023) and another one is nearly complete. The first paper describes the development and testing in the laboratory and in the field of the 3D computational model for the study organism, the fiddler crab all along the eastern coast and Gulf Coast regions of its distribution. The paper describes the  methods for testing the accuracy of Niche Mapper, the generic microclimate model that drives the generic animal model that responds to the hourly changes in climate both behaviorally and physiologically to find the locally available environments that minimize its survival requirements and maximize its potential for growth and reproduction. We demonstrate in that paper a very high degree of accuracy in being able to define the 3D anatomy of the animal and its physiology and from that anatomical, behavioral and physiological data that we obtained from our collaborators. We could calculate the body temperatures and water loss rates of the fiddler crabs anywhere along the East Coast to within half a degree centigrade body temperature and water loss rates to a very high precision for any climatic condition from New York to Florida. This validates yet again the powerful capability to design any kind of animal and determine its physiological and behavioral constraints under any climatic conditions.

 We were able to demonstrate that variation in the animal properties were relatively insignificant compared to the environmental conditions the animals experienced in terms of effects on body temperature, feasible activity times and water loss rates. Thus, the availability of shade and degree of wetness of the beach as well as air temperatures word the driving forces for the ability of these animals to remain above ground and engage in feeding and mating. This indicates that these animals are not likely to be able to evolve major responses in their own properties to withstand climate warming. They will very much be dependent upon the physical environmental conditions available to them wherever they are. Thus climate change poses extraordinary challenges to their survival and distribution. This is important because they are important cleaners of the detritus and other organic materials on our beaches along our coasts.

Now that we know that we have a powerful well tested trustworthy generic model, Niche Mapper, for these animals, we have been able to run annual simulations at hourly intervals with different climate warming scenarios to evaluate how their distributions and their potential for survival are likely to be modified by climate warming. This second paper will also includes a number of sensitivity analyses that dig deeper into the multidimensional animal and environmental variables that do or do not significantly impact their biology and fitness. This work is also significant because it was done in a very challenging microenvironment, namely in the boundary layer at the surface of the ground. To get that right was a new challenge that we met successfully. Reconstructing microclimates from microclimate (airport) data and doing it accurately is a critical process that enables us to assess how climate change will affect animals ranging in size from mosquitoes to cows and moose, which we have done with other funding, in their own local micro environments. The results of those studies show that global climate warming will have differential effects at different latitudes, elevations and hemispheres. The coming climate changes will have substantial economic consequences that will vary with latitude and elevation.(Porter et al. 2023). Fortunately, thanks in part to support from the NSF, we have a mechanistic predictive tool to evaluate those upcoming changes for any species where we can obtain the appropriate anatomical, physiological and behavioral attributes of any species or group of species. Knowing how they will have to respond to climate changes, we can plan for mitigating the changes that will occur for any species of interest, whether it be wild or domestic. This will be extremely important for maintaining our domestic agriculture and food supply.

References 

Mathewson, P. D., M. Z. Darnell, Z. M. Lane, T. G. Yeghissian, J. Levinton, and W. P. Porter. 2023. Incorporating species-specific morphology improves model predictions of thermal and hydric stress in the sand fiddler crab, Leptuca pugilator. Journal of Thermal Biology 115:103613.

Porter, W. P., A. E. Bertz, P. D. Mathewson, L. C. Solorzano, P. N. Dudley, R. Bonazza, and K. G. Gebremedhin. 2023. Climate Spaces and Cliffs: A Novel Bovine Thermodynamic and Mass Balances Model. Animals 13:3043.
